commander.name: Major-General Terry de la Mesa Allen
commander.previous_service: Cavalry officer, WWI veteran. Known for aggressive leadership and unconventional tactics.

tanks.note: Infantry division - no organic tanks. Tank battalions attached for operations (1st Armored Division assets at Kasserine/El Guettar).

artillery.note: Four field artillery battalions (three 105mm, one 155mm). 37mm AT guns inadequate vs German armor.

soft_skin_vehicles.note: Standard US triangular division motor transport allocation

supply_logistics.supply_status: ADEQUATE - Part of Operation Torch logistics buildup. Supply lines from Algerian ports (Oran, Algiers). Fuel at 4 days (constrained), ammunition 3 days (low after Kasserine), water adequate. Division learning desert logistics after initial failures at Kasserine Pass.
notes: Division landed at Oran during Operation Torch (November 1942)
Supply challenges during Kasserine Pass operations
Ammunition expended heavily at El Guettar (March 23)
Learning desert logistics and coordination with British 8th Army
37mm AT guns inadequate - requesting 57mm replacements

weather_environment.terrain_type: Tunisian mountains and passes - Kasserine Pass, Gafsa area, djebels (rocky hills). Mixed terrain: mountain passes, desert plains, olive groves.
notes: Winter conditions in Tunisian mountains
Kasserine Pass operations February 19-24
El Guettar offensive March 23 - desert plains terrain
Rain and mud in mountain passes

subordinate_units.note: Fought at Kasserine Pass and El Guettar
Key role at El Guettar battle

tactical_doctrine.role: Standard triangular infantry division for assault and exploitation operations. First US division to face German forces in Tunisia. Aggressive leadership under Allen and Assistant Division Commander Brigadier-General Theodore Roosevelt Jr.
special_capabilities: Aggressive assault tactics under Allen/Roosevelt leadership
Desert warfare experience (Algeria, Tunisia since Nov 1942)
known_issues: Mauled at Kasserine Pass (Feb 19-24) - first US-German engagement
Limited anti-tank capability - 37mm guns inadequate vs German armor
Discipline issues due to aggressive, unconventional culture
Supply chain challenges in desert terrain
Green troops before Kasserine - learned hard lessons

historical_context.operational_status: Active - Tunisia Campaign (Kasserine Pass, El Guettar)
major_battles: Battle of Kasserine Pass (19-24 February 1943): First US-German engagement, US defeat
Battle of El Guettar (23 March - 7 April 1943): US victory, repulsed German 10th Panzer Division counterattack
Operation Torch landings (8 November 1942): Oran, Algeria
notes: Division nickname: 'Big Red One' (red numeral '1' shoulder patch)
Commander: Major-General Terry de la Mesa Allen (aggressive, unconventional leader)
Assistant Division Commander: Brigadier-General Theodore Roosevelt Jr. (son of President, Medal of Honor D-Day 1944)
Kasserine Pass casualties: 287 KIA, 1,342 WIA, 156 MIA
El Guettar: Defeated German 10th Panzer Division counterattack (23 March)
Division learned hard lessons at Kasserine, performed well at El Guettar
Later: Sicily (July 1943), Normandy D-Day (6 June 1944), across Europe to Germany

source: Nafziger Collection - 943UQIA: Organizational Summary, American Infantry Division, 15 July 1943, Table of Organization T/O 7
Atkinson, Rick. An Army at Dawn: The War in North Africa, 1942-1943 (2002)
MacDonald, Charles B. The Siegfried Line Campaign (CMH Pub 7-7)
1st Infantry Division Historical Records, National Archives
